title: Add ARIA labels and improve semantic HTML structure
description:
Improve accessibility of the AgentiCorp web interface by adding proper ARIA labels
and improving semantic HTML structure throughout the application.

Key improvements needed:
- Add ARIA labels to navigation links for screen readers
- Add proper ARIA roles and focus management to modal dialogs
- Ensure all form inputs have associated labels
- Add skip navigation link for keyboard users
- Verify all interactive elements are keyboard accessible
- Add visible focus indicators on all interactive elements

This addresses WCAG 2.1 Level AA compliance requirements.

Files to modify:
- web/static/index.html
- web/static/css/style.css

title: Replace alert() dialogs with proper modal components
description:
Replace all browser alert() calls with proper modal dialogs for better UX.
Currently, bead details and errors are shown using alert(), which is jarring
and provides a poor user experience.

Key improvements:
- Create a reusable modal component for displaying bead/decision details
- Replace alert() error messages with toast notifications
- Add loading states for all async operations
- Implement success/error feedback for form submissions
- Show visual feedback when spawning agents or performing actions

This will provide a more modern and user-friendly interface.

Files to modify:
- web/static/js/app.js
- web/static/index.html (add modal templates)
- web/static/css/style.css (add toast notification styles)

title: Create informative empty states with call-to-action buttons

informative empty states with helpful actions.

Current issues:
- "No active agents", "No pending decisions" are just plain text

- Missing visual illustrations or helpful prompts

Improvements:

- Include helpful text explaining what each section is for
- Add visual icons or illustrations to empty states
- Provide quick start guidance for new users
- Link to documentation where appropriate

Files to modify:
- web/static/js/app.js (render functions for empty states)
- web/static/css/style.css (empty state styling)
- web/static/index.html (if needed)

title: Improve mobile responsive design and touch targets
description:
Enhance the mobile experience of the AgentiCorp web interface with better
responsive design and appropriate touch targets.

Current issues:
- Kanban columns are very tall on mobile when stacked
- Touch targets may be too small (buttons, cards)
- Modal dialogs may not fit well on small screens
- Abrupt breakpoint transition at 768px
- Tables and long text may overflow on small screens

Improvements:
- Add intermediate breakpoints for tablet sizes
- Ensure minimum touch target size of 44x44px
- Make grid layouts more fluid
- Improve modal sizing on small screens
- Test and optimize for common mobile devices
- Consider collapsible sections for long content on mobile

Files to modify:

Improve the visual design of the AgentiCorp interface with better hierarchy,

Improvements:

title: Add search and filter capabilities for beads and agents
description:
Add search and filtering functionality to help users find and manage
beads, agents, and other resources more effectively.

Current limitations:
- No way to search for specific beads
- Cannot filter beads by status, priority, or tags
- No sorting options
- Cannot see bead relationships (parent/child, blocking)
- Limited visibility into complex work graphs

Proposed features:
- Add search input for beads by title/description
- Filter dropdowns for status, priority, type, and tags
- Sort options (by date, priority, status)
- Visual display of bead relationships
- Quick filters (e.g., "My beads", "Blocked", "High priority")
- Search for agents by name or persona

Files to modify:
- web/static/js/app.js (search and filter logic)
- web/static/index.html (search/filter UI elements)
- web/static/css/style.css (search/filter styling)

title: Add CEO persona + tie-break/deadlock decision workflow (human-in-the-loop)
description:
Create a special "CEO" persona representing the human project owner who resolves
high-level or tie-breaking decisions when other agent personas cannot decide or
reach a deadlock.

Requirements
- CEO is always a human (not an autonomous agent).
- CEO interacts via Web UI, API, or by manually editing bead files in the repo.
- When a deadlock/tie-break is detected, work must be routed to the CEO.
- The CEO must receive precise instructions on what decision is required.
- The CEO must be able to:
  - Comment on the bead/decision
  - Mark: approved | denied | needs_more_info
- If "needs_more_info", the bead should be returned to the last agent who owned
  it (previous assigned_to) and that agent should resume work / respond.

Implementation Notes
- Add a new persona at: personas/examples/ceo/{PERSONA.md,AI_START_HERE.md}
- Extend decision beads (or add a new decision resolution state machine) to
  capture CEO decisions and rationale:
  - decision: approve|deny|needs_more_info
  - rationale/comment (required)
  - returned_to (agent id) when needs_more_info
- Add API endpoints/UI support for:
  - Viewing the decision instructions
  - Adding comments
  - Submitting the CEO resolution (approve/deny/needs_more_info)
  - Returning the bead to the prior agent when needs_more_info
- Add deadlock/tie-break detection rules (initial heuristic is fine):
  - conflicting agent recommendations on same decision bead
  - decision bead timeout / repeated flip-flops
  - explicit "escalate_to_ceo" action

Acceptance Criteria
- CEO persona exists and is discoverable via personas listing.
- A decision bead can be escalated to CEO and shows clear, actionable prompts.
- CEO can resolve a decision via UI and via API.
- CEO can mark needs_more_info and the system reassigns/unblocks work back to
  the last agent who owned the bead.
- End-to-end test covers: escalate -> CEO approve/deny/needs_more_info.

title: P0 - Temporal-controlled clock for dispatch, loop detection, and AgentiCorp parked/active state
description:
Implement a Temporal-driven "clock" (durable scheduler) that ensures AgentiCorp
continuously and reliably dispatches agents to their assigned beads, reacts to
asynchronous work submissions, detects looping/deadlock behavior, and exposes
a visible "parked" state when there is no work.

Goals
- AgentiCorp wakes up on a schedule and on signals/events to:
  - dispatch agents to beads assigned to them
  - re-dispatch beads handed back by agents
  - detect work loops / deadlocks and route appropriately
- If ALL beads in ALL open projects are closed, AgentiCorp transitions to
  status: parked (visible in UI for the CEO).
- Any newly filed bead, or any agent waking and discovering new work,
  transitions AgentiCorp out of parked state.

Requirements
1) Temporal-controlled clock
   - Use Temporal to run a long-lived workflow (e.g., agenticorp-clock) that
     performs periodic polling/dispatch (and uses continue-as-new).
   - Workflow must also accept signals for:
     - bead.created / bead.updated
     - agent.heartbeat / agent.woke
     - bead.returned_for_redispatch
   - The clock triggers AgentiCorp dispatch logic deterministically and reliably.

2) Guaranteed dispatch / redispatch
   - If a bead is assigned_to an agent, AgentiCorp must ensure that agent is
     scheduled/started and picks up the bead (or is marked unhealthy).
   - If an agent hands a bead back to AgentiCorp for redispatch, AgentiCorp must
     wake and take action.

3) Loop / deadlock detection
   - Detect beads being handed back and forth between the same agents with
     repeating/near-repeating comments (initial heuristic is acceptable).
   - On loop detection:
     - Reassign bead to project-manager persona by default
     - If PM is one of the looping agents, escalate to CEO (bd-008)
     - Record rationale in bead context/comments.

4) Parked/active status surfaced in UI
   - Add AgentiCorp system status (active|parked) to UI/API.
   - When parked, CEO can see that AgentiCorp is idle.
   - Any new work event flips status back to active.

Suggested Implementation
- Add a new Temporal workflow: AgentiCorpClockWorkflow
  - Runs periodic tick (e.g., every 30s)
  - Exposes signals for asynchronous triggers
  - On each tick or signal:
    - scan open projects
    - compute open-work set (non-closed beads)
    - update agenticorp status parked/active
    - run dispatch and loop detection actions
- Add a small system-status store (in-memory + optional persistence) and API:
  - GET /api/v1/system/status
- Add UI widget in header to show status.

Acceptance Criteria
- AgentiCorp reliably dispatches assigned beads without manual intervention.
- Redispatch occurs promptly when bead is returned.
- Looping beads are detected and reassigned/escalated.
- AgentiCorp shows parked state in UI when no open work exists.
- Any new bead/event transitions AgentiCorp to active and dispatch resumes.

title: P0 (sticky) Documentation update policy for AgentiCorp
description:
This is a sticky, always-on bead for the AgentiCorp project.

Goal
- Keep user documentation accurate and current for the AgentiCorp project.

Rules
1) README.md (high-level only)
   - Update README.md ONLY when there is a high-level feature change or a new
     Make target that should appear in the project's high-level summary.
   - Do NOT churn README.md for small internal refactors.

2) docs/ directory (always when relevant)
   - For any relevant feature/change, add new docs or update existing docs
     under docs/.
   - Prefer updating an existing doc over creating redundant documentation.

Definition of Done (for any feature bead)
- If the feature is user-facing or changes workflows, docs/ is updated.
- If the change impacts the high-level entrypoint summary, README.md is updated.
- Otherwise, README.md remains unchanged.

title: P1 (sticky) Maintain continuously refreshed architecture diagram
description:
This is a sticky, ongoing bead.

Goal
- Maintain an up-to-date architecture diagram that reflects the current
  AgentiCorp system.

Trigger conditions (update is required when ANY occur)
- A new service is added
- A new agent type or core agent lifecycle feature is added
- A new persona is added or persona responsibilities materially change
- A new feature is added that is tracked as an EPIC bead (must update diagram)

Requirements
- Architecture diagram must be refreshed as necessary and remain accurate.
- Diagram should reflect:
  - Services (API server, Temporal, DB/key manager, UI, etc.)
  - Major subsystems and data flow (beads, decisions, dispatch, event bus)
  - How personas/agents interact with beads and decisions
- Store the diagram in a stable location under docs/ (e.g., docs/architecture/)
  and/or update ARCHITECTURE.md if that is the canonical home.

Conventions
- Prefer a text-based diagram that is easy to diff (Mermaid or ASCII) unless a
  rendered asset is required.
- The diagram should include the date of last update.

Recent Update (January 21, 2026)
- Updated for v1.0 Production Ready milestone completion:
  * Added Provider Routing System (section 3.1)
  * Added Authentication & Authorization System (section 3.2)
  * Updated Provider System to include routing and cost metadata
  * Updated System Overview with new v1.0 capabilities
  * Updated "Last Updated" timestamp to January 21, 2026

Previous Update (January 20, 2026)
- Added comprehensive Mermaid diagrams:
  * System Component Diagram showing all managers and data flow
  * Bead Processing Sequence Diagram
  * Org Chart Structure visualization
- Updated component documentation to include:
  * Org Chart System (section 5)
  * Model Catalog System (section 6)
  * Testing Infrastructure (section 11)
- Preserved legacy ASCII diagram for backwards compatibility
- Renumbered all sections to maintain consistency

title: P1 - Require PRDs for major features (epics) and link PRD + story beads
description:
Update the Product Manager persona behavior:

Policy
- For any major new feature, the Product Manager must:
  1) Write a PRD (Product Requirements Document)
  2) File an EPIC bead for the feature
  3) Reference the PRD from the EPIC bead
  4) Ensure every PRD item is represented by a STORY bead that is a child of
     (or otherwise explicitly associated with) the EPIC bead.

PRD location and naming
- Each PRD must be a uniquely named Markdown file stored at:
    docs/PRD/
  within the project's repository.
- File name must be descriptive and unique (e.g.,
    docs/PRD/agent-dispatch-parking-and-loop-detection.md
  ).

PRD format (markdown)
- Each PRD should include at minimum:
  - Summary / problem statement
  - Goals / non-goals
  - User stories / requirements list (each must map to a story bead)
  - Acceptance criteria
  - Risks / open questions
  - Rollout / migration considerations (if applicable)

Bead linkage requirements
- The EPIC bead must include:
  - A link/path reference to the PRD file (docs/PRD/...) in its description
    and/or context.
  - A checklist or enumerated list mapping PRD sections/items -> story bead IDs.
- Every PRD requirement item must have a corresponding story bead associated
  with the EPIC bead.

Implementation
- Update personas/examples/product-manager/PERSONA.md and AI_START_HERE.md to
  encode this policy and enforcement behavior.
- Add guidance for how to structure PRDs and how to file story beads.

2) Project registration model

Acceptance Criteria

- README.md includes a "Project Registration" section near the top
- Sections are concise, accurate, and link to deeper docs where appropriate

title: P1 - Provider model preference list + negotiation + dynamic scoring
description:
Add a system-level “recommended models” preference list that AgentiCorp uses to
help providers pick the best available model (provider-side negotiation).

Goal
- Each provider implementation should select (“negotiate for”) the best model
  it can serve, guided by AgentiCorp’s recommended model list and a dynamic score
  computed from observed availability/latency/throughput (and later cost).

Requirements
1) Recommended model list (AgentiCorp-owned)
   - AgentiCorp maintains an ordered list of recommended models with per-model
     metadata used for scoring and selection.
   - The model list must support multiple factors per model, including:
     - Estimated total parameter size (e.g., 480B vs 30B)
     - “Active” parameter size when encoded in the name (e.g., A35B)
     - Interactivity class (fast/medium/slow response expectation)
     - Best parallelization hints (e.g., tensor-parallel degree, kv-cache)
     - Suggested minimum GPU memory / GPU class (heuristic)
   - The model list must include (at minimum):
     - nvidia/NVIDIA-Nemotron-3-Nano-30B-A3B-FP8 (already used in bootstrap)
     - Qwen2.5-Coder variants already registered in the system
     - Qwen/Qwen3-Coder-480B-A35B-Instruct
     - Qwen/Qwen3-Coder-30B-A3B-Instruct

2) Provider negotiation
   - Providers should not be pinned to a single fixed model string.
   - On provider registration/update, and periodically (or on demand), a
     provider implementation should:
     - call provider’s model listing endpoint (OpenAI-compatible /models)
     - intersect discovered models with AgentiCorp’s recommended list
     - pick the best eligible model by AgentiCorp-computed score
     - record the selected model in provider state (and expose via API/UI)
   - If a provider cannot serve any recommended model:
     - fall back to its configured model (if present)
     - otherwise pick the best available discovered model by heuristic
     - record rationale in provider context

3) Dynamic model scoring
   - AgentiCorp computes a model score per provider-model candidate based on:
     - availability/health (up/down, error rates)
     - observed latency (TTFB and full completion time)
     - throughput (tokens/sec when measurable)
     - concurrency/queue depth (if measurable)
     - future: dollar cost (when available)
   - AgentiCorp should persist rolling metrics and a current score.

4) Model name decoding / GPU implications
   - AgentiCorp should parse model names to extract useful signals, at minimum:
     - Total parameter count (“480B” > “38B” > “30B”)
     - “Active parameter” count when present (“A35B”, “A3B”)
     - Precision/format hints when present (BF16/FP16/etc)
     - Instruction-tuned vs base (“Instruct”)
   - AgentiCorp should expose derived fields in model metadata so selection and
     UI can explain why a model is chosen.
   - If a provider exposes GPU selection (via its own OpenAPI extensions or
     vendor-specific endpoints):
     - include GPU capability constraints in negotiation (VRAM / GPU type)
     - allow provider-side selection to pick an appropriate GPU for the model
     - record chosen GPU (if any) alongside chosen model.

Suggested Implementation
- Add a ModelCatalog / RecommendedModels component:
  - data model persisted in config DB (and exported/imported via config API)
  - supports model metadata + derived parsed fields
- Add observed metrics and score tracking:
  - per-provider/per-model rolling windows
  - activity instrumentation around chat completion calls
- Extend provider schema/API:
  - configured_model (requested)
  - selected_model (effective)
  - model_score + metrics snapshot
  - optional selected_gpu / gpu_constraints

Acceptance Criteria
- AgentiCorp has a recommended model list with metadata and parsing.
- Providers can auto-select a best model from the recommended list.
- AgentiCorp computes and persists model scores based on real runtime signals.
- Provider state exposes configured vs selected model (and optional GPU).
- The model list includes the Qwen3 Coder 480B and 30B instruct models.

title: P1 - Model catalog + model-name parser (size/active params/format/instruct)
description:
Implement AgentiCorp’s recommended model catalog and model-name decoding.

Scope
- Add an internal ModelCatalog component that stores:
  - canonical model id/name
  - human label
  - interactivity class (fast/medium/slow)
  - parallelization hints
  - GPU heuristics (min VRAM, suggested GPU class)
  - parsed/derived fields from model name

Model list (must include)
- nvidia/NVIDIA-Nemotron-3-Nano-30B-A3B-FP8
- Qwen2.5-Coder models already supported by the system
- Qwen/Qwen3-Coder-480B-A35B-Instruct
- Qwen/Qwen3-Coder-30B-A3B-Instruct

Parsing requirements
- Parse total parameter count from tokens like `480B`, `38B`, `30B`.
- Parse “active” parameter count from tokens like `A35B`, `A3B`.
- Parse precision hints like `BF16`, `FP16`, etc.
- Detect instruct tuning from suffix like `Instruct`.
- Normalize model family/vendor segments when present (e.g. `Qwen/`).

Persistence & API
- Persist catalog in config DB (and include in config export/import).
- Expose via API for visibility (read-only initially is fine).

Acceptance Criteria
- Model catalog exists with required models present.
- Parser produces derived fields for the required models.
- Derived fields are available for scoring/selection and (later) UI display.

title: P1 - Provider model negotiation (configured vs selected model)
description:
Make providers “negotiate” for the best model they can serve, guided by the
AgentiCorp recommended model catalog.

Requirements
- Extend provider state to track:
  - configured_model (requested / preferred)
  - selected_model (effective)
  - selection_reason (why this model was chosen)
  - optional selected_gpu (if provider supports GPU selection)
- Add a negotiation routine that:
  1) calls provider’s OpenAI-compatible `/models`
  2) intersects discovered models with AgentiCorp recommended catalog
  3) ranks candidates by AgentiCorp scoring (initial scoring can be heuristic)
  4) writes back selected_model and reason into provider state
- Run negotiation:
  - on provider create/update
  - and via an explicit API trigger (e.g., POST /api/v1/providers/{id}/negotiate)

Fallback behavior
- If no recommended model matches:
  - use configured_model if present and available
  - else pick the best discovered model by heuristic
- Always store a reason in provider context.

Acceptance Criteria
- Provider shows configured_model vs selected_model.
- Negotiation selects a recommended model when available.
- API trigger causes an immediate re-evaluation.

title: P2 - Provider/model metrics + dynamic scoring (availability/latency/throughput)
description:
Add runtime metrics and a dynamic scoring system to rank provider-model
candidates.

Metrics
- Track per-provider/per-model rolling metrics:
  - success/error rate
  - latency (TTFB if available; otherwise total duration)
  - throughput (tokens/sec when measurable)
  - last_seen_at
- Persist aggregated metrics in config DB (schema TBD).

Scoring
- Compute a score combining:
  - availability/health
  - latency (lower is better)
  - throughput (higher is better)
  - future: dollar cost
- Expose score in provider state and API responses.

Instrumentation
- Capture timing around provider chat completion calls.
- Update rolling metrics upon each request.

Acceptance Criteria
- ✅ Scores exist and update over time based on real request data
- ✅ Metrics are tracked per-provider (success/error rate, latency, throughput)
- ✅ Dynamic scoring combines availability + performance
- ✅ Scores/metrics are visible via Provider API (metrics field)
- ⚠️  Provider negotiation can use scores (GetScore() method available)

Implementation Summary
- Added ProviderMetrics struct tracking:
  * Request counters (total/success/failed)
  * Latency stats (avg/min/max)
  * Throughput (tokens/sec)
  * Computed scores (availability/performance/overall)
- Added Provider.RecordSuccess() and RecordFailure() methods
- Added Provider.GetScore() for overall score (0-100)
- Added metrics callback mechanism to Registry
- Instrumented Registry.SendChatCompletion() to capture timing
- Wired up metrics recording in AgentiCorp via setupProviderMetrics()
- Metrics persisted to database via attributes_json field
- Metrics updates published to event bus

Scoring Formula
- Availability Score (60% weight): health status * success rate
- Performance Score (40% weight): 70% latency + 30% throughput
- Overall Score: 0.6 * availability + 0.4 * performance
- Uses exponential moving average for rolling metrics

title: P2 - UI: show provider configured/selected model, score, and optional GPU
description:
Extend the Web UI to surface provider model negotiation state.

Requirements
- Provider cards/details should show:
  - configured_model (requested)
  - selected_model (effective)
  - selection reason
  - current score + last observed metrics (if available)
  - selected GPU (if reported)
- Provide a UI action to trigger negotiation:
  - "Re-negotiate model" button calling the API trigger.

Acceptance Criteria
- UI clearly differentiates configured vs selected model.
- Negotiation trigger works and updates UI via SSE events (or refresh).

title: P2 - Provider GPU selection hooks (optional, when provider exposes GPU choice)
description:
Add optional GPU selection support for providers that expose GPU topology and
selection controls (e.g., vendor OpenAPI extensions).

Requirements
- Extend provider config/state to optionally include:
  - gpu_constraints (min_vram_gb, required_gpu_arch, allowed_gpu_ids)
  - selected_gpu (effective)
- During negotiation:
  - use model-name-derived size/format + catalog GPU heuristics to filter GPUs
  - pick a GPU that can serve the selected model
  - record selected_gpu (if provider supports it)

Notes
- This must be provider-specific and only enabled if the provider exposes the
  necessary endpoints/fields.

Acceptance Criteria
- ✅ Provider model supports gpu_constraints field (GPUConstraints struct)
- ✅ Provider can record selected_gpu alongside selected model
- ✅ GPU selection logic implemented (SelectGPU function)
- ✅ Constraints can be inferred from model specs (InferGPUConstraintsFromModel)
- ✅ If provider doesn't expose GPU selection, negotiation still works (optional field)

Implementation Summary
- Added GPUConstraints struct to Provider model:
  * MinVRAMGB - minimum VRAM requirement
  * RequiredGPUArch - architecture requirement (ampere, hopper, ada)
  * AllowedGPUIDs - specific GPU device IDs
  * PreferredClass - GPU class preference (A100-80GB, H100, etc.)
- Created GPU selection logic in internal/provider/gpu_selection.go:
  * SelectGPU() - picks best GPU based on model requirements and constraints
  * InferGPUConstraintsFromModel() - derives constraints from ModelSpec
  * Filtering by VRAM, architecture, in-use status, and allowed IDs
  * Selection priority: preferred class → suggested class → most VRAM
- Added comprehensive test suite (7 test cases)
- Database schema updated with gpu_constraints_json field
- Provider model reduced VRAM requirement from 48GB to 24GB for FP8 model
- Changed default model to nvidia/NVIDIA-Nemotron-3-Nano-30B-A3B-FP8 for speed

Notes
- GPU selection is optional and provider-specific
- Works with providers that expose GPU topology APIs
- Falls back gracefully when GPU info not available

title: P2 - Tests: model-name parsing + negotiation ranking + scoring
description:
Add tests to prevent regressions in model parsing and selection.

Requirements
- Unit tests for model-name parser:

Implementation Summary

- Tests cover:
  * ParseModelName with 7 different model name formats
  * Score calculation with various interactivity/size combinations
  * SelectBest negotiation with multiple scenarios
  * Default catalog validation
  * Catalog Replace and Validate operations
- Fixed parsing bug: models with active params (A35B) were incorrectly parsed
- All 8 test functions pass with 31 test cases total

Acceptance Criteria
- ✓ Tests cover the required model names and negotiation behavior
- ✓ All tests pass (go test ./internal/modelcatalog/...)
- ✓ Build remains green

title: P0 - Add CFO persona for provider cost monitoring and budget control
description:
Create a CFO persona responsible for monitoring provider costs, securing a
monthly budget from the CEO, and recommending cost-control measures when
spend is trending high.

Responsibilities
- Track provider spend and forecast monthly burn.
- Request/confirm a monthly budget with the CEO.
- If spend is trending toward early budget exhaustion:
  - Recommend cost controls to AgentiCorp:
    - prefer on-prem providers
    - throttle work rate
    - apply other cost-saving controls
- If staying within budget is not possible:
  - Ask CEO to decide: increase budget OR temporarily pause all work.
  - Convey the CEO decision to AgentiCorp and to the CFO persona.

Implementation Notes
- Add persona files: personas/examples/cfo/{PERSONA.md,AI_START_HERE.md}
- Define CFO coordination workflow with CEO (decision beads or explicit policy)
- Ensure CFO guidance can be surfaced to AgentiCorp policies for routing/throttling

Acceptance Criteria
- CFO persona exists and is discoverable via personas listing.
- CFO behavior includes cost monitoring, budget requests, and cost controls.
- CFO can trigger a CEO decision when budget cannot be met.
- CFO communicates approved decision back to AgentiCorp.

title: P1 - CFO monthly budget review and long-term budget decisions
description:
Extend the CFO persona to perform monthly budget reviews and avoid assuming
that all budget increases are permanent.

Responsibilities
- Perform a monthly budgetary review:
  - compare actual spend vs forecast
  - identify over/under budget trends
- If consistently over budget:
  - ask CEO to decide on a lasting budget increase OR accept slower work to
    stay within the previous budget.
- If consistently under budget:
  - explicitly acknowledge/celebrate this outcome in CFO reporting.

Implementation Notes
- Update CFO persona docs (PERSONA.md + AI_START_HERE.md).
- Add guidance for when to trigger the “lasting decision” vs short-term
  budget adjustments.

Acceptance Criteria
- CFO persona includes monthly budget review responsibilities.
- CFO asks for long-term decisions when overruns persist.
- CFO acknowledges sustained under-budget operation.

title: P0 - Default personas under personas/default + project agent cloning workflow
description:
Update persona structure and agent management to reflect that the shipped
personas are the default roles used by agents.

Requirements
1) Persona directory structure
   - Move default personas from `personas/examples/<role>` to
     `personas/default/<role>` to indicate these are the canonical default
     role templates.

2) Default agents per project
   - Each tracked project has a group of assigned agents.
   - By default, create all standard agent roles documented in README.md.
   - Each default agent uses the corresponding default persona path.

3) Persona cloning (copy-on-write)
   - Add an agent clone method (UI + API) that:
     - clones the default persona for a role
     - writes the clone to a new persona path provided by a human
     - assigns the new persona to a cloned agent instance for that project
   - The original default persona must remain unchanged.

4) Access & control
   - Any user with password access can assign/unassign agents on a project.
   - Any user with password access can trigger persona cloning and edit the
     cloned persona via UI or API.

Acceptance Criteria
- Default personas live in `personas/default/<role>`.
- Projects start with default agents and default personas for each role.
- Persona cloning creates a new per-project persona without modifying the
  default template.
- UI/API supports agent assignment and persona cloning.

title: P0 - Define agent role hierarchy (generic JD vs per-project instances)
description:
Define a hierarchy for agent roles so that each role has a generic “job
description” template, and each project can have customized instances of
those roles.

Concept
- Generic role persona = baseline job description (e.g., CEO, CFO, PM, QA).
- Agent instance = per-project persona that can extend or override the generic
  role instructions without changing the template.

Requirements
- Establish a role hierarchy model:
  - role template (generic default persona)
  - role instance (project-specific persona)
- Allow project-level customization of role instances:
  - start from template
  - modify instructions per agent or project
  - save to project scope only
- Preserve the default template as immutable (copy-on-write behavior).

Notes
- Think of this as job description vs. a specific person hired under that JD.
- Instances can adapt based on project or agent identity.

Acceptance Criteria
- Role hierarchy is defined and documented in the system behavior.
- Project-specific role instances can be created without mutating templates.
- System can resolve which persona to use: instance overrides template.

title: P1 - Deduplicate Makefile targets (build/run/test/clean/docker-build/help)
description:
Resolve duplicate Makefile targets that emit override warnings when running
make build/run/test/clean/docker-build/help.

Context
- make build warns about duplicate target definitions at lines 79 and 23.
- make run warns about duplicate target definitions at lines 92 and 28.
- make test warns about duplicate target definitions at lines 96 and 33.
- make clean warns about duplicate target definitions at lines 118 and 44.
- make docker-build warns about duplicate target definitions at lines 145 and 50.
- make help warns about duplicate target definitions at lines 148 and 5.

Requirements
- Remove or consolidate duplicate targets so each target is defined once.
- Preserve current behavior of each target (build/run/test/clean/docker-build/help).
- Ensure `make build`, `make run`, `make test`, `make clean`, `make docker-build`, and `make help`
  run without override warnings.

Acceptance Criteria
- No override warnings when invoking any of the listed targets.
- Target behavior remains consistent with the intended latest definitions.

title: P0 - Fix build failure: missing modelCatalogKey in agenticorp
description:
Fix the build failure when running make build due to an undefined
modelCatalogKey symbol in internal/agenticorp/agenticorp.go.

Error
internal/agenticorp/agenticorp.go:85:40: undefined: modelCatalogKey

Requirements
- Ensure modelCatalogKey is defined and accessible where referenced.
- Keep model catalog persistence behavior intact.
- make build should complete without errors.

Acceptance Criteria
- go build ./cmd/agenticorp succeeds.
- make build completes without the undefined symbol error.

title: P0 - Fix remaining bead YAML parse warnings
description:
Resolve the remaining YAML parse warnings emitted on startup when loading
bead files. These warnings are currently preventing those beads from loading
cleanly.

Context
- Warnings observed after `make build run`:
  - bd-008-add-ceo-persona-tiebreak-deadlock-workflow.yaml: cannot unmarshal !!seq into string
  - bd-009-temporal-clock-dispatch-loop-detection-and-parking.yaml: cannot unmarshal !!seq into string
  - bd-013-readme-personas-and-project-registration-docs.yaml: cannot unmarshal !!seq into string
  - bd-018-ui-provider-model-status.yaml: mapping values are not allowed in this context
  - bd-020-model-negotiation-tests.yaml: mapping values are not allowed in this context
  - bd-026-fix-build-target-model-catalog-key.yaml: mapping values are not allowed in this context

Requirements
- Update the listed bead YAML files so they parse without warnings.
- Preserve the semantic content of each bead.
- Ensure `make build run` loads all beads without YAML parse warnings.

Acceptance Criteria
- No YAML parse warnings on startup for the listed bead files.
- Beads load successfully and retain their original intent.

title: P0 - Create initial AgentiCorp user guide + GitHub Pages publishing
description:
Create an initial AgentiCorp user guide in markdown format, add a GitHub CI/CD
stage that converts the guide to HTML, and publish it via GitHub Pages.

Requirements
- Add an initial markdown user guide under docs/ (markdown source of truth).
- Add a GitHub Actions workflow stage that builds the markdown into HTML.
- Configure GitHub Pages to publish the generated HTML site for AgentiCorp.
- Ensure the user guide is linked from appropriate documentation entrypoints
  (README.md or docs index as needed).

Acceptance Criteria
- The markdown user guide exists under docs/ and is complete enough for first-time users.
- CI produces HTML output from the markdown source on every main branch update.
- GitHub Pages serves the HTML output successfully under the AgentiCorp repository.

title: P1 (sticky) User guide review by personas before release approval
description:
This is a sticky, always-on bead for the AgentiCorp project.

Goal
- Ensure the AgentiCorp user guide is reviewed and augmented by relevant personas
  before any release can be approved by release engineers.

Rules
1) Release gating
   - A release cannot be approved unless the user guide has been reviewed and
     updated as needed.
2) Required reviewers
   - At minimum: documentation-manager, project-manager, and qa-engineer.
   - Additional personas should be included when their domain is impacted
     (e.g., devops-engineer for deployment changes).
3) Evidence
   - Each release must include a short note in the release checklist or bead
     context confirming the review occurred and describing any updates made.

Definition of Done (for any release bead)
- The user guide has been reviewed by the required personas.
- The guide is updated to reflect any changes in workflows or features.
- Release approval includes the review evidence.

title: P0 - Project management UI must support full CRUD with API parity
description:
The project management UI currently lacks an Add Project button and should
fully support create, read, update, and delete operations. All views should
expose full CRUD in the UI and via the API.

Requirements
- Add UI affordances to create, edit, and delete projects.
- Ensure API endpoints support full CRUD for projects.
- All project views must surface CRUD actions consistently.

Acceptance Criteria
- Users can create, edit, and delete projects from the UI.
- API supports the same CRUD operations with validation and persistence.
- Project list and viewer stay in sync after CRUD actions.

title: P0 - Make build/run/test targets exercise full Docker stack
description:
The current Makefile build/run/test targets run the agenticorp binary directly.
We need these targets to build, run, and test the full Docker stack (including
Temporal and any required services) so we are not running in a crippled mode.

Requirements
- Update build/run/test targets to use docker compose (or equivalent) to build
  and run the full container stack.
- Ensure tests run with Temporal and other dependencies available.
- Preserve developer convenience while making the default targets validate
  the full system.

Acceptance Criteria
- `make build`, `make run`, and `make test` exercise the containerized stack.
- Temporal is running during test execution.
- The targets provide clear logs and failure output.

title: P0 - Temporal tests skipped because Temporal is not running
description:
Running `make test` shows Temporal-related tests are skipped because the
Temporal server is not available. This indicates the tests are not exercising
the full system.

Evidence
- internal/temporal tests skipped with errors like:
  "failed reaching server: dial tcp 127.0.0.1:7233: connect: connection refused"
- internal/temporal/eventbus tests skipped for the same reason.

Requirements
- Ensure Temporal is running during test execution (via docker compose or
  a test harness) so these tests run instead of skipping.
- Update test setup to fail fast if Temporal is expected but not available.

Acceptance Criteria
- Temporal-related tests run and pass during `make test`.
- The test suite fails if Temporal cannot be reached when required.

title: P0 - Provider heartbeat self-tests via Temporal scheduling
description:
Each provider should run a scheduled self-test/heartbeat workflow in Temporal
to ensure it is still responding. Providers that fail their heartbeat should
be automatically marked disabled until they recover, so dispatch avoids them.

Requirements
- Add a Temporal-scheduled heartbeat workflow per provider.
- Define a provider self-test action that validates responsiveness.
- Automatically disable providers after heartbeat failures.
- Automatically re-enable providers once heartbeats succeed again.
- Dispatch must skip disabled providers and fall back to healthy ones.

Acceptance Criteria
- Heartbeat workflows are scheduled and observable for each provider.
- Providers fail closed when heartbeats fail and recover automatically.
- Work selection never targets disabled providers.

title: P0 - make test must always pass
description:
The `make test` target should always pass in the default development and CI
environments. This is a sticky requirement to prevent regressions that break
the primary test workflow.

Requirements
- Ensure `make test` passes without manual intervention.
- Keep this requirement sticky across future changes.

Acceptance Criteria
- `make test` completes successfully on a clean checkout.
- Failures or skips are addressed or surfaced as P0 regressions.

title: P0 - CEO REPL for high-priority AgentiCorp queries
description:
Add a CEO-facing REPL at the bottom of the UI to send high-priority
questions directly to AgentiCorp through Temporal.

Requirements
- Add a CEO REPL section in the UI with textarea input and response display.
- Route queries through Temporal as a high-priority workflow.
- Use AgentiCorp persona context and select the best provider by quality/latency.
- Surface provider/model metadata in the response.

Acceptance Criteria
- CEO can submit a query and receive a response in the UI.
- Requests run through Temporal workflows (not direct provider calls).
- Provider selection favors high-quality, low-latency providers.

title: P0 - Provider bootstrap initialization on registration
description:
When a provider is registered, AgentiCorp must bootstrap it by discovering the
correct OpenAI-compatible (vLLM) or Ollama-compatible endpoint/port, loading
models, negotiating the best model, persisting metadata, and starting the
heartbeat workflow.

Requirements
- Provider status starts as pending.
- Provider bootstrap discovers the correct port/protocol (OpenAI /v1 or Ollama).
- Provider bootstrap lists available models and negotiates the best model.
- Persist selected_model, selection_reason, model_score, and endpoint updates.
- Provider status transitions to healthy or failed with an error string.
- Heartbeat workflow starts and continues to keep status up to date.

Acceptance Criteria
- Newly registered providers become healthy automatically when reachable.
- Newly registered providers become failed (with error) when unreachable.
- Dispatch avoids non-healthy providers.

title: P0 - Org Chart Abstraction Layer for Project-Agent Association
description:
When a project is first registered (e.g., via bootstrap or API), the system
currently spawns default agents but lacks a proper abstraction for the
"org chart" - the set of agents assigned to work on a project.

Problem Statement
- Projects are created without a formalized org chart structure
- Agents are directly associated to projects via a simple []string Agents field
- No concept of "default org chart" that every new project should receive
- No hierarchy support for sub-projects inheriting or overriding org charts
- No clean separation between "role slots" and "agent instances filling them"

Proposed Abstraction: OrgChart

An OrgChart is a new model that sits between Project and Agent:

```go
// OrgChart defines the agent team structure for a project
type OrgChart struct {
    ID          string            `json:"id"`
    ProjectID   string            `json:"project_id"`
    Name        string            `json:"name"`           // e.g., "Default", "Custom"
    Positions   []Position        `json:"positions"`      // Role slots in the org
    IsTemplate  bool              `json:"is_template"`    // If true, this is a template
    ParentID    string            `json:"parent_id"`      // For inherited org charts
    CreatedAt   time.Time         `json:"created_at"`
    UpdatedAt   time.Time         `json:"updated_at"`
}

// Position represents a role slot in an org chart
type Position struct {
    ID           string   `json:"id"`
    RoleName     string   `json:"role_name"`       // e.g., "ceo", "product-manager"
    PersonaPath  string   `json:"persona_path"`    // e.g., "default/ceo"
    Required     bool     `json:"required"`        // Must be filled
    MaxInstances int      `json:"max_instances"`   // 0 = unlimited
    AgentIDs     []string `json:"agent_ids"`       // Currently assigned agents
    ReportsTo    string   `json:"reports_to"`      // Position ID of manager
}
```

Hierarchy Model
- Default OrgChart Template: System-wide template with all default roles
- Project OrgChart: Instance created for each project, initially cloned from template
- Sub-Project OrgChart: Can inherit from parent project or use custom structure

Project Hierarchy
- Projects can have sub-projects (ParentID on Project model)
- Sub-projects can inherit org chart from parent or define their own
- Agents can be shared across project hierarchy or scoped to specific level

Agent Instance Model
- Agent = instance of a persona working on a specific project
- Each agent fills one or more positions in an org chart
- Persona = Job Description (what the role does)
- Agent = Person in the role (specific instance with state)

Bootstrap Flow Changes
1. System defines DefaultOrgChartTemplate on startup
2. CreateProject() creates a new OrgChart cloned from template
3. ensureDefaultAgents() becomes ensureOrgChart() - fills required positions
4. Agents are spawned to fill positions, not just "added to project"

API Changes
- GET /api/projects/{id}/org-chart - Get project's org chart
- PUT /api/projects/{id}/org-chart - Update org chart structure
- POST /api/projects/{id}/org-chart/positions - Add position
- DELETE /api/projects/{id}/org-chart/positions/{posId} - Remove position
- POST /api/projects/{id}/org-chart/positions/{posId}/assign - Assign agent
- DELETE /api/projects/{id}/org-chart/positions/{posId}/agents/{agentId} - Unassign

Database Changes
- New table: org_charts
- New table: org_chart_positions
- Add parent_id to projects table for sub-project support

Migration Path
- Existing projects get org chart created from their current Agents list
- Existing agents mapped to positions based on persona name

Acceptance Criteria
- [x] OrgChart and Position models defined in pkg/models
- [x] OrgChartManager created in internal/orgchart
- [x] Default org chart template defined from personas/default/* roles
- [x] Project.CreateProject() creates org chart from template
- [x] Sub-project support with parent_id on Project model (schema & model support added)
- [x] API endpoints for org chart CRUD (GET /api/v1/org-charts/{projectId})
- [x] Database schema for org charts and positions (tables created in initSchema)
- [x] Migration for existing projects/agents (ImportFromLegacy method available)
- [x] UI shows org chart structure in project view (agents sorted by org chart hierarchy)
- [x] Tests for org chart operations

Implementation Notes
- OrgChart Manager currently uses in-memory storage (matching provider/agent managers)
- Database schema exists and ready for future persistence layer
- UI displays agents in org chart order (CEO -> CFO -> PM -> EM, etc.)
- API auto-creates org chart on first GET if not exists
- Legacy migration method available via ImportFromLegacy()

title: Web Interface UX Improvements
description:
Epic grouping all UX improvements identified by the Web Designer persona's 
comprehensive review of the AgentiCorp web interface.

This epic covers accessibility, usability, visual design, responsive design,
and interactive features to improve the overall user experience.

Key areas addressed:
- Accessibility and WCAG compliance
- Modern modal and feedback patterns
- Informative empty states
- Mobile responsive design
- Visual hierarchy and consistency
- Search and filter capabilities

Related document: personas/default/web-designer/UX_REVIEW_FINDINGS.md

title: Real-time Response Streaming Support
description:
Implement streaming support for real-time AI responses using Server-Sent Events
(SSE) or WebSocket, improving perceived performance and user experience.

Problem: Currently, users must wait for complete responses before seeing any 
output, leading to poor perceived performance.

Goals:
- Implement Server-Sent Events (SSE) or WebSocket support
- Add streaming handlers for provider responses
- Update web UI to display streaming content
- Maintain backwards compatibility with non-streaming endpoints

Success Criteria:
- Responses begin displaying within 500ms
- Streaming works for all configured providers
- Fallback gracefully for providers without streaming support
- Web UI updates smoothly without flickering

User Impact: All users benefit from faster perceived response times and better 
interactivity.

Related document: personas/default/product-manager/FUTURE_GOALS.md (BEAD-001)

title: Authentication and Authorization System
description:
Implement authentication and authorization to enable secure multi-user deployments
and safe cloud hosting of AgentiCorp instances.

Problem: AgentiCorp currently has no authentication, making it unsafe to expose 
beyond localhost. This limits deployment options and prevents team usage.

Goals:
- Add API key authentication for REST endpoints
- Support multiple authentication methods (API keys, OAuth, JWT)
- Implement role-based access control (admin, user, read-only)
- Add user management interface
- Secure provider credentials per user/team

Success Criteria:
- Endpoints require authentication by default
- Multiple users can have separate provider credentials
- Admin can manage user permissions
- Failed auth attempts are logged
- Compatible with reverse proxy authentication

User Impact: Enables team deployments and safe cloud hosting.

Related document: personas/default/product-manager/FUTURE_GOALS.md (BEAD-002)

title: Advanced Provider Routing Logic
description:
Implement intelligent provider selection based on cost, latency, and capabilities
to optimize for best results at lowest cost.

Problem: Current provider selection is manual and doesn't optimize for cost or 
performance. Users may unknowingly use expensive providers for simple tasks.

Goals:
- Implement cost-aware routing (prefer cheaper providers)
- Add latency monitoring and low-latency routing
- Support capability-based routing (route based on model features)
- Create routing policies (e.g., "minimize cost", "minimize latency", "maximize quality")
- Add automatic failover to backup providers

Success Criteria:
- Can route requests based on configurable policies
- Tracks provider performance metrics
- Automatically fails over when providers are unavailable
- Reduces costs by 30%+ compared to naive routing
- User can override routing policy per request

User Impact: Users save money and get better performance automatically.

Related document: personas/default/product-manager/FUTURE_GOALS.md (BEAD-003)

title: Request/Response Logging and Analytics
description:
Implement comprehensive logging and analytics to provide visibility into usage
patterns, costs, and provider performance.

Problem: Users have no visibility into their usage patterns, costs, or provider 
performance over time.

Goals:
- Log all requests and responses (with privacy controls)
- Track costs per provider and per user
- Create analytics dashboard showing usage trends
- Export usage data for external analysis
- Alert on unusual spending patterns

Success Criteria:
- All requests are logged with metadata
- Dashboard shows usage by provider, model, user, time
- Cost tracking is accurate to provider pricing
- Logs can be exported in standard formats
- Privacy controls prevent sensitive data leakage

User Impact: Users gain insights into spending and can optimize usage.

Related document: personas/default/product-manager/FUTURE_GOALS.md (BEAD-004)

title: Custom Provider Plugin System
description:
Create a plugin system to allow users to add support for custom AI providers
without modifying AgentiCorp's source code.

Problem: Users can't easily add new providers without modifying AgentiCorp's 
source code, limiting flexibility.

Goals:
- Define provider plugin interface
- Support loading plugins from external files
- Provide plugin development guide and examples
- Create plugin registry/marketplace concept
- Support both HTTP and native (SDK-based) providers

Success Criteria:
- Users can add providers without code changes
- Plugin API is well-documented
- Example plugins exist for common providers
- Plugins can handle streaming, auth, and errors
- Plugin crashes don't crash AgentiCorp

User Impact: Extends AgentiCorp to any LLM provider without waiting for official 
support.

Related document: personas/default/product-manager/FUTURE_GOALS.md (BEAD-005)

title: Response Caching Layer
description:
Implement intelligent response caching to save money on duplicate requests and 
provide faster responses for common queries.

Problem: Identical or similar requests result in redundant API calls, wasting 
money and time.

Goals:
- Implement intelligent response caching
- Cache based on request similarity (exact match, semantic similarity)
- Configurable cache TTL and size limits
- Cache invalidation policies
- Respect provider-specific caching rules
- Optional Redis backend for distributed caching

Success Criteria:
- Cache hit reduces cost to zero for that request
- Cache responses return in <50ms
- Cache hit rate >20% for typical usage
- Users can control caching per request
- Stale data is never returned

User Impact: Reduced costs and faster responses for common queries.

Related document: personas/default/product-manager/FUTURE_GOALS.md (BEAD-006)

title: Load Balancing and High Availability
description:
Enable distributed deployment of AgentiCorp for high load handling and redundancy.

Problem: Single AgentiCorp instance becomes a bottleneck and single point of failure.

Goals:
- Support distributed deployment
- Shared state via external database (Redis/PostgreSQL)
- Load balancer integration
- Health check endpoints
- Graceful shutdown and startup
- Session affinity options

Success Criteria:
- Multiple instances can run concurrently
- State is synchronized across instances
- Health checks accurately report status
- Zero-downtime deployments possible
- Scales horizontally under load

User Impact: Enterprise users can deploy AgentiCorp at scale with high availability.

Related document: personas/default/product-manager/FUTURE_GOALS.md (BEAD-007)

title: IDE Integration Plugins
description:
Create plugins for popular IDEs to enable developers to use AgentiCorp directly 
from their editor without context switching.

Problem: Users must leave their IDE to interact with AgentiCorp through web UI 
or separate tools.

Goals:
- Create VS Code extension
- Create JetBrains plugin
- Create Neovim/Vim plugin
- Provide extension API for other IDEs

Sub-features to implement:
- VS Code extension with AI chat panel
- Inline code suggestions from AgentiCorp
- JetBrains plugin
- Vim/Neovim integration

Success Criteria: Developers can access AgentiCorp features without leaving 
their editor.

User Impact: Seamless integration into developer workflows.

Related document: personas/default/product-manager/FUTURE_GOALS.md (BEAD-008)

title: Advanced Persona Editor UI
description:
Create a visual editor for creating and customizing personas without manual 
YAML/Markdown editing.

Problem: Creating custom personas requires understanding file formats and manual 
editing.

Goals:
- Web-based persona editor
- Templates for common persona types
- Visual workflow builder for agent behaviors
- Persona testing and validation
- Import/export functionality

Success Criteria:
- Non-technical users can create personas
- Changes preview in real-time
- Personas validate before saving
- Examples and templates available

User Impact: Lower barrier to entry for persona customization.

Related document: personas/default/product-manager/FUTURE_GOALS.md (BEAD-009)

title: Team Collaboration Features
description:
Enable effective team collaboration on agent-driven projects with shared workspaces
and real-time updates.

Problem: AgentiCorp is currently single-user focused, limiting team collaboration.

Goals:
- Shared workspaces
- Real-time collaboration on beads
- Agent work visibility across team
- Commenting and discussion threads
- Team usage analytics

Sub-features to implement:
- Multi-user workspace support
- Shared bead board with real-time updates
- Team member permissions
- Activity feed and notifications
- Team cost tracking and budgets

Success Criteria: Teams can effectively collaborate on agent-driven projects.

User Impact: Enables team workflows and coordination.

Related document: personas/default/product-manager/FUTURE_GOALS.md (BEAD-010)

title: Cost Optimization Recommendations
description:
Provide automated suggestions on how to reduce AI costs through analysis of 
usage patterns.

Problem: Users may not know they're using expensive providers when cheaper 
alternatives exist.

Goals:
- Analyze usage patterns
- Recommend provider substitutions
- Suggest prompt optimizations
- Identify caching opportunities
- Recommend batching strategies

Success Criteria:
- System identifies potential savings >10%
- Recommendations are actionable
- Can automatically apply some optimizations
- Shows projected cost impact

User Impact: Users reduce costs through automated recommendations.

Related document: personas/default/product-manager/FUTURE_GOALS.md (BEAD-011)

title: Implement Server-Sent Events (SSE) or WebSocket support for streaming
description:
Add streaming infrastructure to enable real-time AI response delivery using
Server-Sent Events or WebSocket protocol.

Tasks:
- Design streaming protocol (SSE vs WebSocket tradeoffs)
- Implement server-side streaming handlers
- Add connection management and reconnection logic
- Handle streaming errors and fallback scenarios
- Add streaming endpoints to API

Acceptance:
- SSE or WebSocket endpoint implemented
- Connection lifecycle properly managed
- Errors handled gracefully with fallback
- API documentation updated

title: Add streaming handlers for provider responses
description:
Implement provider-specific streaming handlers to process chunked responses
from LLM providers and forward them to clients.

Tasks:
- Add streaming support to provider interface
- Implement OpenAI-compatible streaming
- Handle chunked response parsing
- Add token-by-token forwarding
- Test with multiple provider types

Acceptance:
- All provider implementations support streaming
- Responses stream token-by-token
- Works with existing non-streaming providers
- Provider errors during streaming handled properly

title: Update web UI to display streaming content
description:
Modify the web interface to consume and display streaming responses in real-time
as they arrive from the server.

Tasks:
- Add EventSource or WebSocket client code
- Implement progressive content rendering
- Add loading/streaming indicators
- Handle stream completion and errors
- Ensure smooth UI updates without flickering

Acceptance:
- UI displays content as it streams in
- No flickering or visual glitches
- Loading states clearly indicate streaming
- Stream errors shown to user
- Responses begin displaying within 500ms

title: Maintain backwards compatibility with non-streaming endpoints
description:
Ensure that existing non-streaming API endpoints continue to work and that
clients can choose between streaming and non-streaming modes.

CANCELLED: Not needed - codebase has not shipped any releases yet, no external 
clients exist. Both streaming and non-streaming modes ship together from initial release.

Tasks:
- Keep existing non-streaming endpoints functional ✓ (implemented from start)
- Add streaming flag/parameter to API ✓ (implemented from start)
- Implement graceful fallback for unsupported providers ✓ (implemented from start)
- Test both modes with all providers ✓ (implemented from start)
- Document streaming vs non-streaming usage ✓ (implemented from start)
